data.text: A feeling that one would like to have or do something or to see something happen; a desire, longing, or strong inclination for a specific thing.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: An expression of a desire, longing, or strong inclination.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: carried out the wishes included in the will.

data.text: An expression of desire for the happiness or success of another.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: finally got his wish to see the ocean.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To feel or express a desire for.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: I wish them good luck. He wished her good night.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: I wish you to go. I wish it to be known that I disagree.

data.text: To desire (something bad) to happen to someone.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: I would not wish such an illness on anyone.

data.text: To have or feel a desire.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
